botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort, skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling.
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grown in moisture retentive neural to alkaline soil that is not prone to drying out. Best planted in a sunny position or light shade. Improve lighter soil with organic matter such as garden compost or a manure-based soil conditioner prior to planting. Mulch annually in spring. For more details, see hellebore cultivation.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division in early autumn or in early spring after flowering. Propagate by seed as soon as ripe and keep in a coldframe.
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove faded leaves in late summer/autumn.
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to hellebore aphis, slugs and snails.
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to hellebore black death, hellebore leaf spot, grey moulds (botrytis) and virus diseases.
